| **Prospective cohort studies** (e.g., EPIC, NIH‑AARP, Nurses’ Health Study, Health Professionals Follow‑up Study) | Association between self‑reported meat intake and later cancer incidence. | Large sample sizes, long follow‑up, ability to adjust for many confounders. | Dietary recall error, residual confounding, cannot prove causality. |
| **Case‑control studies** | Compare past diet of people with cancer vs. controls. | Efficient for rare cancers. | Recall bias, selection bias. |
| **Randomised controlled feeding trials** (e.g., WHI Dietary Modification, PREDIMED‑sub‑studies) | Directly test effect of diet changes on intermediate biomarkers (e.g., DNA damage, inflammatory markers) and, rarely, cancer outcomes. | Highest internal validity for the intervention tested. | Short duration, small numbers, ethical limits on long‑term cancer outcomes. |

| **Meta‑analyses & systematic reviews** | Summarise many studies to estimate pooled risk. | Increase statistical power, assess consistency. | Quality depends on included studies; heterogeneity can be large. |
| **Expert‑panel assessments** (IARC, WHO, US Dietary Guidelines, American Cancer Society, EFSA) | Weigh all evidence and assign a risk classification. | Transparent, multidisciplinary, consider both epidemiology and mechanistic data. | Occasionally lag behind newest primary research; may differ in weighting of evidence. |

| Hazard | How it forms | Which cooking styles generate the most? |

| **Advanced glycation end‑products (AGEs)** | Form in dry‑heat cooking; they are linked to oxidative stress. | Roasting, baking at very high temperatures. |
| **Nitrite‑derived N‑nitroso compounds** | Mostly a concern for processed meats (cured with nitrite); can also arise from high‑temperature cooking of unprocessed meat, but the contribution is small. | Same high‑heat methods, especially when the meat is pre‑cured.
